mentions.context: In the continuity of the PlantCLEF challenges organized in previous years [4][5][6][7][8][9][10][11][12], the LifeCLEF 2020 Plant identification challenge presented in this paper was designed to evaluate to what extend automated identification on the flora of data deficient regions can be improved by the use of natural history collections of herbarium sheets.

The LifeCLEF 2020 Plant Identification challenge (or "PlantCLEF 2020") was designed to evaluate to what extent automated identification on the flora of data deficient regions can be improved by the use of herbarium collections.

3 Participants and methods 68 participants registered for the PlantCLEF challenge 2020 and downloaded the data set, and 7 research groups succeeded in submitting a total of 49 runs, i.e. files containing the predictions of the system(s) they ran.
As it can be Fig. 2. Density grid maps by number of species of geolocated plant specimens in the PlantCLEF2020 dataset.

As expected regarding the low number of field photos in the training set for numerous species, directly fine-tuned CNNs with the PlantCLEF 2020 training set obtained the lowest scores (ITCR PlantNet Run 1, SSN Run 1&2, UWB Run 1).

The species were chosen based on the most comprehensive estimates possible from different data sources (iDigBio, GBIF, Encyclopedia of Life, Bing and Google Image search engines, that were actually provided by the organizers or some participants of previous editions of PlantCLEF and ExpertCLEF challenges).

It provides some improvements on the main evaluation metric as demonstrated with the UWB runs 2 & 3 and ITCR PlantNet Run 2. All these runs extended the training data with the PlantCLEF 2019 training data [7] and the GBIF training data provided by [17]).

The best result was obtained with an ensemble of several variations of FSADA models, while the best single model was using 3 taxonomic levels (species, genus, family) and external datasets (PlantCLEF 2019 [7] and GBIF [17]).

First, two InceptionV4 CNNs [19] were fine-tuned, one exclusively with the herbarium sheets related to the 997 classes, and an other one with more than 1 million pictures related to 10k classes from the PlantCLEF 2017 dataset [5].

ITCR PlantNet Run 2 made a greater improvement on the main MRR metric probably because they used a two stage training strategy: they first fine-tuned a pre-trained ResNet50 with all the herbarium sheets from PlantCLEF 2020, and then finetuned it again with all the field photos PlantCLEF 2020 and the external training data (Plant-CLEF 2019 and GBIF).

The networks are then fused in a final embedding layer trained to optimize the distances between two embeddings based on triplet loss, but only on the subset of 435 classes that contain both herbarium sheets and field photos in the PlantCLEF 2020 training set.

The species were chosen based on the most comprehensive estimates possible from different data sources (iDigBio, GBIF, Encyclopedia of Life, Bing and Google Image search engines, that were actually provided by the organizers or some participants of previous editions of PlantCLEF and ExpertCLEF challenges).

ITCR PlantNet Run 2 made a greater improvement on the main MRR metric probably because they used a two stage training strategy: they first fine-tuned a pre-trained ResNet50 with all the herbarium sheets from PlantCLEF 2020, and then finetuned it again with all the field photos PlantCLEF 2020 and the external training data (Plant-CLEF 2019 and GBIF).

The species were chosen based on the most comprehensive estimates possible from different data sources (iDigBio, GBIF, Encyclopedia of Life, Bing and Google Image search engines, that were actually provided by the organizers or some participants of previous editions of PlantCLEF and ExpertCLEF challenges).
